Course Section: ARCL_V 309-001 - The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
ARTH_V 300-002 - Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History
Course Section Definition Public Notes: This seminar will appeal to art history majors and other upper-level students interested in historical and theoretical investigations of media and visual culture. Through discussion and the close reading of artworks and texts, students will become familiar with a range of influential and contentious approaches to defining Art and evaluating cultural artifacts. We will practice humility and learn to recognize power dynamics and patterns of objectification as we consider what is involved in acts of interpretation, classification, periodization, and speaking for objects and others.

Course Section: ARTH_V 309-001 - Arts of Africa and the African Diasporas
Course Section Definition Public Notes: Engaging with hands-on research based on the African collections of the UBC Museum of Anthropology, this course takes a comparative and historical approach to the arts of Africa and the African diasporas, exploring distinct formulations of what constitutes art in different parts of Africa and diasporic contexts. The course explores key debates that have framed the histories of African Art – tradition vs. innovation vs. authenticity; ethnic arts vs. national arts; art practices under colonial rule; modern African nations and national arts; international circulation of African arts and artists; markets, ownership, repatriation and reparation – and investigates their contemporary resonances.

The eighteenth century – often referred to as the “Age of Enlightenment” – saw a series of profound social, geopolitical, and philosophical changes throughout Europe and the world at large. This course examines the artistic responses to these political and cultural revolutions beginning with the death of King Louis XIV of France (1715) through the “Romantic” revolutions of the 1830s. While attending most closely to European art, global trade networks and the spread of colonialism will bring us into contact with artistic movements in the Americas, the Caribbean, and East Asia.

Course Section: ARTH_V 341-001 - 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
Course Section Definition Public Notes: American and European Art since 1945: What is Post-Modernism? provides an overview of visual art across media and the built environment  in Europe and its North American diaspora from 1945 to 2008, situated within their social, political, and historical contexts with a special emphasis on major movements of the neo avant-garde which include The New York School, The Aesthetics of Indifference, Pop, Minimalism, Happenings, Performance, text-based Conceptual Art Installation, Delegated Performance and the repeated “return” of the avant-gardes, specifically of Dada and the readymade. Special emphasis is placed on the theoretical and social turns of the post medium condition, and above all on the advent of identity politics as a central criteria of art after the dissolution of the importance of skill-based media.

Course Section: ARTH_V 358-001 - Chinese Art for the Afterlife
Course Section Definition Public Notes: Tombs are not only important repositories for art objects and archaeological artefacts, they are also architectural structures that integrate objects and images into a spatial logic and create multi-layered meanings: Tombs are spaces of transformation, ritual spaces, and liminal zones; they envision the afterlife and show the tomb occupants’ ambitions. We will conduct case studies of Chinese tombs with a focus on the period between the Han and Yuan dynasties (third century BCE to the fourteenth century) to explore ideas about the afterlife, materiality, intercultural exchange, and the articulation of social identities.

Course Section: ARTH_V 362-001 - Art in Japan: Objects and Spaces
Course Section Definition Public Notes: ARTH 362 explores the changing relationship between spaces and things in the Japanese archipelago. Students will learn to account for the co-imbrication of (art) objects and architectural typologies within changing social contexts. Students will be evaluated based on a combination of cumulative revision (exams) and individual research output.

Course Section: ARTH_V 377-001 - Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples (The South): Re-Examining Underrecognized Visual Cultures of Southern British Columbia, Washington, & the Peripheries 
This lecture-based course examines ancient and historical Indigenous art forms of the southern Northwest Coast, defined as southern British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and northern California. This region is severely underrepresented in Native Northwest art history, where scholarship tends to emphasize the bold, colorful artwork emanating from northern First Nations including the Haida, Tlingit, and Tsimshian. Redirecting our attention to local settings, we explore the more understated, abstract material culture found in southern locales, with a particular focus on Coast Salish art. In addition, we investigate why different genres of Northwest Coast art exist, and how these diverse styles have been categorized, classified, and even mischaracterized by scholars throughout the decades. Through textual analysis, discussion, research, and public art on campus, we will investigate various mediums: petroglyphs and stone carvings in archaeological contexts; monumental art, architecture, and welcome posts; and belongings such as masks, regalia, and weavings. By the end of the course, you will be able to identify nuances in southern Northwest Coast artistic expression, hypothesize possible reasons for these differences, and possess a greater understanding of Native art traditions in proximity to Vancouver and UBC. 

(Note: This course is now offered as part of UBC’s newly required “Ways of Knowing” curriculum, where ARTH 377 is listed as a “Place & Power” class. Place & Power courses offer students new ways to examine local landscapes through the lenses of settler colonialism, decolonialism, Indigeneity, environmental justice, etc.)
